rows.name: text
rows.value: Your goal was to spend one-on-one time with your teen.

rows.name: outro_text
rows.value: Well done for coming up with solutions to your challenges. Go try them out. Your relationship with your teen will get stronger and stronger!

rows.name: question_text_1
rows.value: Which of the tips helped you?

rows.name: choice_2
rows.value: PLAY – Let your teen choose the activity.

rows.name: choice_3
rows.value: STAY – Give your teen all of your attention.

rows.name: question_text_2
rows.value: Why was this tip helpful for you?

rows.name: answer_list_choice_1
value: name:choice_1_a | text:Having a specific time to do this helps me to remember.
name:choice_1_b | text:With a routine, my teen and I can both keep our schedule free.
name:choice_1_c | text:Spending time with my teen every day helps to build trust with them/him/her.

rows.name: reply_choice_1
rows.value: Ah yes, even 10 minutes together makes a big difference – that makes it easy to schedule it in next to your work and chores!

rows.name: answer_list_choice_2
value: name:choice_2_a | text:Letting my teen choose what to do builds their confidence.
name:choice_2_b | text:If my teen chooses, s/he is more likely to want to spend time together.
name:choice_2_c | text:Letting my teen choose shows that I care about his/her interests.
name:choice_2_d | text:By accepting my teen’s suggestions, I am showing that I listen to him/her.
name:choice_2_e | text:Saying something nice about my teen’s choice helps them feel valued.

rows.name: reply_choice_2
rows.value: So true! And if our teens choose, they are encouraged to also take responsibility in other areas of their lives.

rows.name: answer_list_choice_3
value: name:choice_3_a | text:By preventing interruptions, I am showing my teen that s/he is most important.
name:choice_3_b | text:Even if I can’t join my teen’s activity, like sports, I can still cheer them on.
name:choice_3_c | text:When I pay attention, I can learn so much about my teen’s interests, views and capabilities.

rows.name: reply_choice_3
rows.value: Yes! If we give our teens our full attention, they will more likely do the same for us the next time we ask them for something!

rows.name: text_1
rows.value:
Many parents experience challenges in having one-on-one time with their teens. 

Here are the top 8 challenges parents told us they experience while trying to either schedule or spend one-on-one time with their teen. If you experienced one of these or are afraid that you will, please select an option to get a possible solution. You will be able to choose another option afterwards.

rows.name: question_text_1a
rows.value: Did you have any challenges when trying to spend time with your teen?

rows.name: question_text_1b
rows.value: What challenge did you have when trying to spend time with your teen?

rows.name: text_challenge_2
rows.value: My teen does not want to spend time with me.

rows.name: text_challenge_3
rows.value: My teen only wants to watch TV or play on his/her phone.

rows.name: text_challenge_4
rows.value: My teen wants to do things that are not safe or that cost money.

rows.name: text_challenge_5
rows.value: My teen wants to do things that I cannot physically do.

rows.name: text_challenge_6
rows.value: My teen chose a competitive activity. I won and s/he got angry.

rows.name: text_challenge_7
rows.value: I struggled to end the one-on-one time.

rows.name: text_challenge_8
rows.value: All my children want one-on-one time with me at the same time.

rows.name: text_other_challenge
rows.value: My challenge is not listed here.

rows.name: reply_challenge_1
rows.value: I know it can be hard to find time during the day, with work, chores, and everything else.

rows.name: reply_challenge_2
rows.value: Sorry that you struggled with that. It can make us feel bad if our children do not want to spend one-on-one time with us.

rows.name: reply_challenge_3
rows.value: Sorry that you had that challenge. Children often want to spend time watching T.V. or playing with a gadget. Well done for being patient with your teen!

rows.name: reply_challenge_4
rows.value: You are not alone here. Many parents sometimes have this challenge, too. One-on-one time should always be safe, and it does not have to cost a thing!

rows.name: reply_challenge_5
rows.value: Sorry to hear this. Our teens may be disappointed if we cannot do what they want to do, like playing sports or doing other physically demanding activities. But remember, what is most important is that we spend time with them; that may look different for everyone!

rows.name: reply_challenge_6
rows.value: This sometimes happens! Competitive games can be challenging for teens (and adults!) if they have difficulty with losing.

rows.name: reply_challenge_7
rows.value: I know the end of one-on-one time can sometimes be difficult.

rows.name: reply_challenge_8
rows.value: Many parents are also faced with this. It can be difficult to spend one-on-one time with our teens when we have more than one child.

rows.name: question_text_2
rows.value: Do you want to try one of the following things?

rows.name: answer_list_challenge_1
value: name:choice_1_a | text: Think of a time each day that I can spare five minutes or a bit more time.
name:choice_1_b | text: Find a chore that we could do together in a fun way.
name:choice_1_c | text: Ask my teen or someone else to help me with a chore, so I have some extra free time.

rows.name: reply_choice_1_a
rows.value: Perfect; even spending 5 minutes makes a big difference, and if you do it at the same time every day (like at breakfast or before bed), it will be easier to keep it up!

rows.name: reply_choice_1_b
rows.value: Great! That way you get your work done and have a fun time together with your teen!

rows.name: reply_choice_1_c
rows.value: Wonderful! By sharing responsibilities, you will have more time to do something fun with your teen – it’s so important!

rows.name: answer_list_challenge_2
value: name:choice_2_a | text: Think of a time when my teen is more open to me, like in the morning or right before bedtime.
name:choice_2_b | text: Sit next to my teen when they are doing something they enjoy and show interest in what they like.
name:choice_2_c | text: Do something fun with the whole family.

rows.name: reply_choice_2_a
rows.value: Great! Picking a time when your teen is more talkative will help them to respond well to your attempt to connect.

rows.name: reply_choice_2_b
rows.value: Nice! Watching your teen’s favourite T.V. show or sports match together will show them that you care. Just be patient; they will open up to you over time!

rows.name: reply_choice_2_c
rows.value: Perfect! Sometimes it can be easier to start with spending time with the whole family. That way your teen can get more comfortable with spending one-on-one time with you over time.

rows.name: answer_list_challenge_3
value: name:choice_3_a | text: Suggest fun things my teen and I could do together.
name:choice_3_b | text: Find something educational to do with my teen on the gadget.
name:choice_3_c | text: Ask my teen to show me how their phone/gadget works.

rows.name: reply_choice_3_a
rows.value: That’s perfect! If you need any inspiration, we can give you ideas of what you could do together! In a minute, we will give you a list of suggested activities. Remember, let your teen choose!

rows.name: reply_choice_3_b
rows.value: Wonderful!  There are lots of fun apps on phones that you can play together. Ask questions, show interest, and remember to say something nice.

rows.name: reply_choice_3_c
rows.value: Nice! Teens love it when you show interest in their gadget and when they get to explain something they know to you. This is a great starting point!

rows.name: answer_list_challenge_4
value: name:choice_4_a | text: Explain to my teen why their suggestion is not safe or possible and ask them for other ideas.
name:choice_4_b | text: Suggest other fun activities that we could do together.

rows.name: reply_choice_4_a
rows.value: Awesome! It is very important that your teen understands why you cannot do the activity that they suggested. Ask them for other ideas!

rows.name: reply_choice_4_b
rows.value: This is perfect! If you need any inspiration, you can find suggestions for activities in your @global.parent_centre . Remember, let your teen choose the activity!

value.fullExpression: This is perfect! If you need any inspiration, you can find suggestions for activities in your @global.parent_centre . Remember, let your teen choose the activity!

rows.name: answer_list_challenge_5
value: name:choice_5_a | text: Watch my teen do the activity and cheer them on.
name:choice_5_b | text: Suggest other fun activities we can do together.

rows.name: reply_choice_5_a
rows.value: Wonderful! Even if you are watching instead of doing the activity together, you can show your interest by describing and praising what your teen is doing!

rows.name: reply_choice_5_b
rows.value: That’s perfect! If you need any inspiration, you can find suggestions for activities in your @global.parent_centre . Remember, let your teen choose the activity!

value.fullExpression: That’s perfect! If you need any inspiration, you can find suggestions for activities in your @global.parent_centre . Remember, let your teen choose the activity!

rows.name: answer_list_challenge_6
value: name:choice_6_a | text: Suggest other activities that we can do together instead of against each other.
name:choice_6_b | text: Play the activity in teams, so I can encourage my teen if our team loses.

rows.name: reply_choice_6_b
rows.value: If you and your teen are in the same team, you can help them manage their emotions if your team loses.

rows.name: answer_list_challenge_7
value: name:choice_7_a | text: Say to my teen, “We have one minute before the end of one-on-one time today”, so my teen is prepared.
name:choice_7_b | text: Inform my teen of how much time I have for one-on-one time and ask them to keep track on a clock or watch.
name:choice_7_c | text: Plan one-on-one time right before another activity that my teen enjoys.

rows.name: reply_choice_7_a
rows.value: Wonderful! By giving your teen a heads-up, the end of one-on-one time will not come as a surprise. Also, you can remind your teen that you will spend time together again tomorrow.

rows.name: reply_choice_7_b
rows.value: Great! That way your teen has the responsibility to monitor the time and will be aware when time is almost up. Remind them that you will spend time together again tomorrow.

rows.name: reply_choice_7_c
rows.value: Wonderful! If you spend time together right before dinner, you can happily say, “One-on-one time is over. Let’s get ready for dinner with the rest of the family!”

rows.name: answer_list_challenge_8
value: name:choice_8_a | text: Ask another adult or older sibling to look after the younger children during the one-on-one time with my teen.
name:choice_8_b | text: Think of a time when the other children are not around and spend time with my teen then.
name:choice_8_c | text: Plan one-on-one time in a place other than at home.

rows.name: reply_choice_8_a
rows.value: Perfect! This way, you can give your undivided attention to your teen, so they feel valued and loved.

rows.name: reply_choice_8_b
rows.value: Great! You can try spending time with your teen when the other children have already gone to bed, or are playing outside.

rows.name: reply_choice_8_c
rows.value: Wonderful! Maybe you can walk to the shops together or go watch a sports match, so you can chat without having the other children demand your attention.

rows.name: text
rows.value: Your goal was to introduce ONE positive consequence for your teen taking responsibility and ONE negative consequence for your teen breaking a household rule. We noticed you tapped the @global.parent_point @data.habit.consequence.title - great job for remembering!

value.fullExpression: Your goal was to introduce ONE positive consequence for your teen taking responsibility and ONE negative consequence for your teen breaking a household rule. We noticed you tapped the @global.parent_point @data.habit.consequence.title - great job for remembering!

Your goal was to introduce ONE positive consequence for your teen taking responsibility and ONE negative consequence for your teen breaking a household rule. We noticed you tapped the @global.parent_point @data.habit.consequence.title - great job for remembering!

rows.name: text
rows.value: Your goal was to introduce ONE positive consequence for your teen taking responsibility and ONE negative consequence for your teen breaking a household rule.

rows.name: question_text_happy
rows.value: Did you have any challenges when trying to introduce a consequence together?

rows.name: question_text_ok_sad
rows.value: What was difficult for you about introducing a consequence with your teen?

rows.name: text_challenge_1
rows.value: I got angry when my teen broke the rule, so I did not introduce the consequence calmly.

rows.name: reply_challenge_1
rows.value: Oh, we know exactly how this feels! Try to take a pause before responding. This really helps us to calm down and respond better. Next time your teen makes you angry, take five deep breaths before responding.

rows.name: text_challenge_2
rows.value: I introduced the consequence without first discussing it with my teen.

rows.name: reply_challenge_2
rows.value: OK. Can you make a consequence for if this happens again? When we establish a consequence together with our teens, the consequence will be more realistic, and our teens will be more willing and able to follow the rule.

rows.name: text_challenge_3
rows.value: Even with the consequence, my teen still does not follow the rule.

rows.name: reply_challenge_3
rows.value: Nothing ever works all the time, but these parenting skills can make rules work better. Try to keep going with your STAR habits – like self-care, one-on-one time, and praise. Remember, all these skills will help your teen to follow the rules more often!

rows.name: text_challenge_4
rows.value: We only created a negative consequence, not a positive consequence.

rows.name: reply_challenge_4
rows.value: It can be difficult to think of positive consequences sometimes. Positive consequences will encourage your teen to take more responsibility, and you will see the difference!

rows.name: text_challenge_5
rows.value: My teen suggested being hit as a negative consequence.

rows.name: reply_challenge_5
rows.value: Teens can be used to seeing hitting as the only possible consequence for breaking rules. Brainstorm some calm consequences with them that could help them understand that they have done something wrong; these consequences should not involve hitting them. These will be more effective and will set positive examples!

rows.name: text
rows.value: Your goal was to discuss a possible crisis situation with your teen and make a plan for it.

rows.name: hp_description_third_plural
rows.value: prepare for a possible crisis with their teens

rows.name: hp_description_second_singular
rows.value: prepare for a possible crisis with your teen

rows.name: text_challenge_1
rows.value: My teen told me that something serious happened to them and I did not know how to handle it.

rows.name: reply_challenge_1
rows.value: Praise your teen for telling you; that is not easy to do! Remember, you can use all the skills you picked from your toolbox: Take a pause, use the four steps of problem solving, and reach out to get the support you and your teen need!

rows.name: text_challenge_2
rows.value: The conversation made me very uncomfortable because I was reminded of a negative experience I had.

rows.name: reply_challenge_2
rows.value: When we are reminded of such experiences, it is normal to feel upset or angry. It is important to find a time when you are calm, so that you can think of what support you need. You may need to talk to someone.

rows.name: text_challenge_3
rows.value: One of us did not feel comfortable.

rows.name: reply_challenge_3
rows.value: This is difficult stuff to talk about. Find a relaxing time for it. We know it is much easier to not talk about these things and to hope they will never happen to us. However, learning to deal with crisis is like getting insurance; it is ALWAYS best to think about them and be prepared.

rows.name: text
rows.value: Your home practice was to try out REAL, POSITIVE and EXACT instructions with your teen.  We noticed you tapped the @global.parent_point @data.habit.spend_time.title - great job for remembering!

value.fullExpression: Your home practice was to try out REAL, POSITIVE and EXACT instructions with your teen.  We noticed you tapped the @global.parent_point @data.habit.spend_time.title - great job for remembering!
Your home practice was to try out REAL, POSITIVE and EXACT instructions with your teen.  We noticed you tapped the @global.parent_point @data.habit.spend_time.title - great job for remembering!

rows.name: text
rows.value: Your home practice was to try out REAL, POSITIVE and EXACT instructions with your teen.

rows.name: outro_text
rows.value: Thank you for sharing! Well done for trying to give your teen positive instructions and for building a positive relationship with your teen. Your teen deserves praise and YOU deserve praise as well! If you ever need any help, I am here.

rows.name: question_text_1
rows.value: Which of the tips helped you?

rows.name: choice_1
rows.value: GET REAL – Can your teen do what you are about to ask?

rows.name: choice_2
rows.value: GET POSITIVE – Use positive words and praise them!

rows.name: choice_3
rows.value: GET CLEAR – Be clear and specific!

rows.name: reply_choice_1
rows.value: Wonderful! When we ask our teen to do something that is realistic, it is easier for them to succeed.

rows.name: reply_choice_2
rows.value: When we praise them, our teens feel encouraged to listen to us again!

rows.name: reply_choice_3
rows.value: Awesome! When we think ahead of specific instructions to give our teen, our instructions become much easier to follow!

rows.name: text_1
rows.value: Here are some challenges that thousands of parents have when trying to give a realistic, positive and exact instruction.

rows.name: text_challenge_1
rows.value: My teenager did not want to follow the instruction.

rows.name: text_challenge_2
rows.value: I did not find time to spend one-on-one time with my teen.

rows.name: text_challenge_3
rows.value: I gave a negative instead of a positive instruction.

rows.name: text_challenge_4
rows.value: I shouted at my teen when they behaved negatively, instead of giving them a positive instruction for what they should do.

rows.name: text_other_challenge
rows.value: My challenge is not listed here.

rows.name: reply_challenge_1
rows.value: I know; our children need time to learn to follow instructions. Be patient, try again, and remember to praise them every time they follow an instruction!

rows.name: question_text_challenge_2
rows.value: Do you want to try one of the following things?

rows.name: answer_list_challenge_2
value: name:choice_2_a | text: Think of a time each day that I can spare five minutes or a bit more time.
name:choice_2_b | text: Find a chore that we could do together in a fun way.
name:choice_2_c | text: Ask my teen or someone else to help me with a chore, so I have some extra free time.

rows.name: reply_choice_2_a
rows.value: Perfect; even spending 5 minutes makes a big difference, and if you do it at the same time every day (like at breakfast or before bed), it will be easier to keep it up!

rows.name: reply_choice_2_b
rows.value: Great! That way you get your work done and have a fun time together with your teen!

rows.name: reply_choice_2_c
rows.value: Wonderful! By sharing responsibilities, you will have more time to do something fun with your teen – it’s so important!

rows.name: reply_challenge_3
rows.value: I know; it takes some time to get used to giving positive instructions – it’s really worth trying again! Think about the behaviour you would love to see your teen do more and think of positive ways to give that instruction!

rows.name: reply_challenge_4
rows.value:
It is difficult to come up with instructions while we are still angry. Try and find a time when you are calm to introduce a positive instruction to your teen. 

Next time we chat, we’ll talk more about how we can manage our emotions!

rows.name: text
rows.value: Your goal was to make a family budget and savings plan.

rows.name: outro_text
rows.value: Thank you for sharing your experiences! Well done for thinking about how you can budget and save with your family. This will really help you to work towards your family goals. Together you can achieve so many good things!

rows.name: hp_description_third_plural
rows.value: make a budget together with their family

rows.name: question_text_happy
rows.value: Did you have any challenges when making your budget together?

rows.name: question_text_ok_sad
rows.value: What challenges did you have when making your budget together?

rows.name: text_challenge_1
rows.value: I did not want to tell my family how much I earn.

rows.name: reply_challenge_1
rows.value: You don’t have to reveal the exact amount you earn; you could give an estimate. You could say, “In this household, we have @global.monthly_income_estimate every month” rather than, “I make @global.monthly_income_precise”.

value.fullExpression: You don’t have to reveal the exact amount you earn; you could give an estimate. You could say, “In this household, we have @global.monthly_income_estimate every month” rather than, “I make @global.monthly_income_precise”.

You don’t have to reveal the exact amount you earn; you could give an estimate. You could say, “In this household, we have @global.monthly_income_estimate every month” rather than, “I make @global.monthly_income_precise”.

rows.name: text_challenge_2
rows.value: When budgeting, we could not agree on what should fall under needs and what should fall under wants.

rows.name: reply_challenge_2
rows.value: People’s wants and needs are different sometimes. Talking about them together can help you and your teen to understand each other, respect your differences, and see where you can compromise.

rows.name: text_challenge_3
rows.value: I did not understand what to do.

rows.name: reply_challenge_3
rows.value: I’m sorry to hear this. I know it can be difficult! Why don’t we go through it again? Your teen or other family members can join and help you!

rows.name: text_challenge_4
rows.value: My teen did not want to do the budgeting with me.

rows.name: reply_challenge_4
rows.value: Try making the budget with other adults in your home first. Your teen may get interested in what you are doing. Making a budget may sound serious but try to make it fun – make it a game during one-on-one time! Or you can try to make the budget for @global.w_money_grandma first. Remember to praise them when you are done!

value.fullExpression: Try making the budget with other adults in your home first. Your teen may get interested in what you are doing. Making a budget may sound serious but try to make it fun – make it a game during one-on-one time! Or you can try to make the budget for @global.w_money_grandma first. Remember to praise them when you are done!

rows.name: outro_text
rows.value: You deserve some praise, too. Thank you again for using @global.parent_app . It shows you really care!

value.fullExpression: You deserve some praise, too. Thank you again for using @global.parent_app . It shows you really care!

rows.name: text_1
rows.value: Your goal was to praise your teen. You’ve marked the @global.parent_point @data.habit.praise_teen.title @fields.weekly_parent_point_praise_teen this week. Great job for remembering!

value.fullExpression: Your goal was to praise your teen. You’ve marked the @global.parent_point @data.habit.praise_teen.title @fields.weekly_parent_point_praise_teen this week. Great job for remembering!
Your goal was to praise your teen. You’ve marked the @global.parent_point @data.habit.praise_teen.title @fields.weekly_parent_point_praise_teen this week. Great job for remembering!
Your goal was to praise your teen. You’ve marked the @global.parent_point @data.habit.praise_teen.title @fields.weekly_parent_point_praise_teen this week. Great job for remembering!

rows.name: text_2
rows.value: Your goal was to praise your teen.

rows.name: question_text_1
rows.value: Did you have a chance to praise your teen this week?

rows.name: reply_no
rows.value: It can sometimes be hard to remember to praise our teens. Next time you spend one-on-one time with your teen, try and think of one thing you can praise them for. You can even say, “Thank you for spending time with me!”.

rows.name: reply_yes
rows.value: Well done - great job for remembering!

rows.name: answer_list_2
value: name:choice_3 | text: My teen did not like it
name:choice_4 | text: I do not know

rows.name: reply_1
rows.value: Remember, it takes some time for your teen to get used to seeing you praise them. The more time you spend with them, the better it will go!

rows.name: reply_2
rows.value: Well done for observing how your teen felt; keep it up!

rows.name: reply_3
rows.value: It happens; just be patient. Make sure to keep spending time with your teen, so they will value your opinion more and more. When your praise is genuine, you will see the benefits soon!

rows.name: reply_4
rows.value: No problem; try to observe how they respond the next time!

rows.name: text
rows.value: Your goal was to make ONE rule with your teen this week.

rows.name: outro_text
rows.value: Well done for this! It’s not easy, and teenagers won’t keep to the rules all the time, but making a few key rules together is a great start. Praise yourself for trying this; we are proud of you!

rows.name: question_text_happy
rows.value: Did you have any challenges when trying to make a rule together?

rows.name: question_text_ok_sad
rows.value: What was difficult for you about making a rule with your teen?

rows.name: text_challenge_1
rows.value: My teen and I could not agree on a rule.

rows.name: reply_challenge_1
rows.value: Think about whether the rule is reasonable. Can your teen follow it? When making rules as a family, it helps to think about your teen, how old they are, and what really matters to them.

rows.name: text_challenge_2
rows.value: My teen felt it was unfair that they have to follow the rule while I don’t have to follow it.

rows.name: reply_challenge_2
rows.value: We should always remember that children learn best from us. The more we follow the rules, they more they will follow the rules, too. You can adjust the rule to make sure that it is realistic for everyone to follow, considering your responsibilities and your teen’s responsibilities (for example, school or work activities).

rows.name: text_challenge_3
rows.value: I felt uncomfortable, because I feel that I, not my teen, should be the one establishing the rule.

rows.name: reply_challenge_3
rows.value: When we establish rules together with our teens, it helps everyone to understand each other better. The rules will be more realistic, and our teens will be more willing to follow the rules.

rows.name: text_challenge_4
rows.value: My partner felt uncomfortable, because they feel that they, not the teen, should be the one establishing the rule.

rows.name: reply_challenge_4
rows.value: When we all establish the rules together, we will understand one another better. The rules will be more realistic, and teens will be more willing and able to follow the rules.

rows.name: text_challenge_5
rows.value: When we tried to set a rule, we got into an argument.

rows.name: reply_challenge_5
rows.value: Was your teen in a good mood when you tried to set the rule? It is best to approach this when the situation is calm. If you or your teen are tired or hungry, it is better to talk about rules at a later time.

rows.name: text_challenge_6
rows.value: We were not able to stick to the rule.

rows.name: reply_challenge_6
rows.value: The rule needs to be specific and realistic. Make sure to have a rule that can be kept easily, e.g., have one meal together every week instead of every night. Do you need to be more flexible about the rule?

rows.name: text
rows.value: Your goal was to map risks and support systems, both in your community and online, with your teen.

rows.name: hp_description_third_plural
rows.value: map risks and support with their teens

rows.name: hp_description_second_singular
rows.value: map risks and support with your teen

rows.name: text_challenge_1
rows.value: My teen and I disagreed on which areas and online activities were unsafe.

rows.name: reply_challenge_1
rows.value: Well done for trying the activity! When we listen to our teenagers, even if we disagree, we learn to understand their thinking. Try and find time to do the activity again. This time, try to really listen and show you understand them before expressing your thoughts.

rows.name: text_challenge_2
rows.value: My teen identified the house of someone I trust as unsafe. I was shocked and did not what to do.

rows.name: reply_challenge_2
rows.value: It is shocking to learn that people who are close to us and who we trust may be a danger to our teens. Find someone you can talk to about this, perhaps a friend or support service, so you can get the support your need. Remember to take a pause when you are stressed.

rows.name: text_challenge_3
rows.value: My teen insisted that the bar is safe for them to visit. I don’t know how to convince my teen that it is not a safe area.

rows.name: reply_challenge_3
rows.value: Create a safe space to talk with your teen when you are both calm. Listen to your teen’s thoughts about why they feel the bar is safe, and then share your thoughts on why you feel the bar is not safe. Think about making a rule together that allows them to still have fun but stay safe. Teenagers listen better when we speak to them calmly.

rows.name: text_challenge_4
rows.value: As an adult, I feel I am responsible for protecting my child. When I told my teen which areas or online activities are unsafe, my child got angry.

rows.name: reply_challenge_4
rows.value: Our teenagers may know things about our communities and technology that we are not aware of. When we actively involve our teens in the mapping activity, they feel heard and valued, and it can be easier to come up with a plan that everyone agrees on.

rows.name: text_challenge_5
rows.value: It was hard to identify resources available in my community because I don’t know my community so well.

rows.name: reply_challenge_5
rows.value: It is difficult to know every detail about our communities. Involve another family member or friend in your mapping activity. You can even visit some of the services available and ask what they do. The more we know, the better we can keep our families safe!

rows.name: text_challenge_6
rows.value: I don’t know much about technology, so I don’t know how to talk about it with my teen.

rows.name: reply_challenge_6
rows.value: Ask your teen to explain the gadgets they use; you could do this  during one-on-one time). This is a great opportunity to show interest in your teen’s life and to discuss potential risks together. If you are not sure which rules to set, you can always agree, with your teen, to try a new rule for two weeks and then discuss how things are going and change the rule if needed!

rows.name: text
rows.value: Your goal was to try and resolve a problem or conflict together with your teen.

rows.name: reply_challenge_1_2
rows.value: When we have a problem, we always want to get to the quickest end result and can forget about the steps. To come up with the best solution together, it is helpful to first have a full understanding of the problem and the different solutions.

rows.name: hp_description_second_singular
rows.value: resolve the problem with your teen

rows.name: text_challenge_1
rows.value: I forgot the steps of problem solving.

rows.name: text_challenge_2
rows.value: I started with the solutions right away.

rows.name: text_challenge_3
rows.value: We could not agree on a solution to try out and we got into an argument.

rows.name: reply_challenge_3
rows.value: Sometimes it can be difficult to agree with everyone in the family, especially if everyone is not yet calm. You could agree to try one solution first, and then another. Also, if you get stuck, try to get together later to agree on the solution together.

rows.name: text_challenge_4
rows.value: I got angry when the problem came up and I forgot to use the problem-solving steps.

rows.name: reply_challenge_4
rows.value: When a problem comes up, we all get angry or stressed sometimes. Remember, when you feel angry or stressed, you can take a pause to help you stay calm and then solve the problem you are facing.

rows.name: text_challenge_5
rows.value: My teen got angry and did not want to talk about the problem.

rows.name: reply_challenge_5
rows.value: Try to listen to your teen and pay attention to their emotions. If they need some time to calm down, create a time later in the day or week to discuss and solve the problem together. By taking your time, the problem can be solved well.

rows.name: text
rows.value: This week your parenting habit was to breathe and take a pause when you feel stressed. We noticed you tapped the @global.parent_point @data.habit.breathe.title - well done!

value.fullExpression: This week your parenting habit was to breathe and take a pause when you feel stressed. We noticed you tapped the @global.parent_point @data.habit.breathe.title - well done!
This week your parenting habit was to breathe and take a pause when you feel stressed. We noticed you tapped the @global.parent_point @data.habit.breathe.title - well done!

rows.name: text
rows.value: This week your parenting habit was to breathe and take a pause when you feel stressed.

rows.name: text
rows.value: Did you talk with your teen about how you both felt about something stressful?

rows.name: question_text
rows.value: How did this make you feel?

rows.name: hp_description_third_plural
rows.value: talk to their teens about how they feel

rows.name: question_text_happy
rows.value: Did you experience any of these?

rows.name: question_text_ok_sad
rows.value: What was difficult for you about sharing how you feel with your teen?

rows.name: text_challenge_1
rows.value: I was afraid my teen would think I was weak.

rows.name: reply_challenge_1
rows.value: Sharing feelings, especially the difficult ones, sets an important example for your teen! It actually makes everyone in the family stronger, because you can understand and support each other better.

rows.name: text_challenge_2
rows.value: I felt uncomfortable about naming specific difficult feelings.

rows.name: reply_challenge_2
rows.value: Being specific is not rude or insensitive; it really helps others to understand you clearly and this prevents confusion in the family. Feelings like anger and stress are part of our lives. All we need to do when we feel angry and stressed is handle our emotions well by taking a few deep breaths before responding.

rows.name: text_challenge_3
rows.value: My teen felt uncomfortable when I shared my feelings.

rows.name: reply_challenge_3
rows.value: Starting a new thing is always difficult at first. Give yourselves some time to get used to it and keep showing a good example by observing and sharing your feelings. Over time, your teen will learn to do the same, and they will feel even more loved and cared for!

rows.name: text_challenge_4
rows.value: When I shared my feelings, my teen asked many questions, which made me uncomfortable.

rows.name: reply_challenge_4
rows.value: Sharing feelings is about explaining how you are feeling so your teen is aware and learns to do the same. You can choose how much detail you want to share about the situation. It’s up to you! You can also choose to answer questions later by saying, “I am feeling angry/stressed now. Could you please give me some time? We can talk about this more tonight”.

rows.name: text_challenge_5
rows.value: I was too stressed or angry to try sharing my feelings – I prefer to be alone when I feel like that.

rows.name: reply_challenge_5
rows.value: It’s okay to not want to share at that time. Find some time to explain later, when you feel calmer, so that everyone can understand.

rows.name: intro_text
rows.value: Let's listen to an audio together!

rows.value: It's time to learn and practice together!

rows.value: Let’s do a 30 second relaxation activity together.

rows.name: intro_text
rows.value: Let’s do a short relaxation activity together – it will take less than 1 minute and you will feel more relaxed.

rows.name: outro_text
rows.value:
You are a star!

Every day, recognise something you have done well. Reward yourself with something that makes you happy. And take a deep breath to relax.

rows.name: intro_text
rows.value:
Home practice is how we make our family life better. But it often brings challenges. 

Let's share our successes and problems, and help each other find new ideas to try!

rows.name: text
rows.value:
Think about how your home activities went this week. 

Take turns to discuss: 
- What went well and what was a problem? 
- What solutions can you think of together? 
- Pick one solution and try it later with your teen! 

(Or you can even practice it now so it will be easier later!)

rows.name: intro_text
rows.value:
It's great to see you again! 

Let's start with caring for you.

rows.name: text
rows.value:
Take turns:
- Share: How are you feeling today?
- Praise someone in your group for something they did well this week!

Remember that no matter how you feel, it’s great you are here. You all deserve praise.

rows.name: intro_text
rows.value: It's great to see you again!

rows.name: intro_text

rows.name: bottom_text
rows.value:

You are fantastic.

rows.name: activity_text
rows.value:
At the end of the day, take a minute to: 

- Talk to your teen about one fun thing they did. 
- Praise yourself for one thing you did well today. 
- You are a star!

rows.name: activity_text
rows.value:
- Ask each other, “What made you happy today?”
- Ask each other, “What difficulty did you face today?”
- Ask each other, “How can I help you?”
- Try to do this together every day; it could be when you are eating dinner together or before you go to bed.

rows.name: activity_text
rows.value:
- You can’t always travel, but you can always dream! Ask your teen these questions:
- Where would you want to travel to? How long would you be away? What would you pack? What would you do on your trip? What would you see?
- Look at a map together or draw one.
- Choose a country that your teen has never heard of and learn more about the country.

rows.name: activity_text
rows.value: You and your teenager can plan a guestlist of the famous people you’d most like to invite to your party. You can each have five people – they can be from the past or from the present time. Who would you invite? And would your guests get on well together?

rows.name: activity_text
rows.value:
- Think of three statements about yourself. Two must be true and one must be a lie.
- It might help to think of wishes, dreams, experiences at school, likes or dislikes. For example: I hate bananas, my favourite subject is science, and I really wish I could sing. 
- Say them to your teenager and ask them to guess which one is a lie. 
- Did they guess correctly? Was it a surprise?
- Now ask them to do the same. Did you learn something new about each other?

rows.name: activity_text
rows.value: Tell your teenager something about when you were a teenager yourself. What things didn’t exist then? Phones with internet? What did you do for fun? What did you worry about? Don’t worry if they don’t tell you something in return – what’s important is that they listen and remember. Sometimes our teenagers forget that their parents are people too!

rows.name: activity_text
rows.value:
- Think of a superpower. For example, going anywhere instantly, travelling in time, reading minds. 
- Ask your teen, “If you had the superpower to […], how would you use it?”
- Encourage them to give their superhero a name and act it out. 
- Now let your teen choose a superpower for you.
- Make sure you act out your superpower, too!

rows.name: activity_text
rows.value:
Have a conversation with your teen about something they like.

It can be about anything they choose to talk about: sports, friends, music, celebrities…

Try to listen to your teen and give them space to talk.

rows.name: activity_text
rows.value:
- Choose a storyteller to start making up a story.
- Story listeners can interrupt with a word at any time.
- Storyteller needs to fit that word in their story.
- When the story is finished, try with a different storyteller!

rows.name: activity_text
rows.value:
- Think of three different situations. For example, driving a car, sailing a boat or flying a plane.
- Say them to your teen and ask, “Which would you prefer?”
- Ask them why?
- Now think of three more situations or ask your teen to do it for you.

rows.name: activity_text
rows.value:
- Ask each other questions. They can be any questions about things you like or what you did today.
- The only rule is that you can’t answer “Yes”, “No” or “Maybe”.
- How long can you last? How creative can you get with your answers?
- Swap over and play again!

rows.name: activity_text
rows.value:
- First person says, “On Saturday, I am going to… (e.g., go to the park)”
- Second person adds to first person, “On Saturday, I am going to the park and… (e.g., visit my best friend).
- Each person adds to the previous, trying to think of all of the fun things to do on Saturday.

rows.name: activity_text
rows.value:
- Start the story with “Once upon a time there was a…”
- Let your teen make up the next sentence.
- Then you make up a sentence.
- Take turns until you have a wonderful new story.
- Make sure to end the story on a positive note.
- Ask your teen what was their favourite part of the story!

rows.name: activity_text
rows.value:
- Ask your teen what kind of meal they would like to eat. 
- Prepare it together!    
- Let them have a turn at being the head chef – they lead, and you follow their instructions. 
- You can even help them to make a budget for the ingredients! 

Don’t think it will work? Ask your teens what THEY would like for you and them to do together. Let them lead. Relax. Have fun.

rows.name: activity_text
rows.value:
- Create a set of dance moves to your teen's favourite songs. 
- One person does a dance move and everyone else copies it.  
- Everyone takes turns being the leader. 
- Perform it for the household!

rows.name: activity_text
rows.value:
- This game can be played in pairs or with many people in a group.
- Stand facing each other or in a circle. 
- One person leads first and everyone else copies them, trying to move exactly at the same time as the leader.
- Make sure the leader moves slowly enough for everyone else to follow! Explore moving different body parts and in different levels.
- After a while, switch who is leading. Give everyone a chance to lead.
- Try it with no leaders!

rows.name: activity_text
rows.value: Praise time! Look at your teen and praise them for one thing they are doing well! And when was the last time you praised yourself or another adult in your household? Try it!

rows.name: activity_text
rows.value:
- Think of a new skill you could learn together with your teen. For example, keeping a ball in the air or your foot, juggling, making soup?
- Take turns in trying the new skill out.
- Make sure to praise each other, and try to learn and play together!

rows.name: activity_text
rows.value:
- Come up with three types of exercise together. For example, walking, jogging, soccer or dancing.
- Pick one together and try it out. 
- If you both like it, decide how often you are going to do it. Once or twice a week? Every morning?
- Together think of ways to make it even more fun. Can you jog to a certain point? Take turns in being the coach? Motivate each other with a small free reward?

rows.name: activity_text
rows.value:
- The first person gets to choose or sing a song.
- Everyone else must guess the name of the tune (to make it harder they can guess the singer).
- The first one to guess it right becomes the next leader.

rows.name: activity_text
rows.value:
This game is best with at least 3 people.
- Start in a circle and pass one “snap” around the circle (or a “clap” if you cannot snap).
- You “snap” once to throw the “snap”, and once to catch it. Look at the person you are throwing it to.  
- The direction (up, down, straight, curved, rolling the ground) and force (hard, soft, medium) that you throw the snap should affect how the person catches it.  
- You can bounce the “snap”, throw it in the air, and catch it a few times before passing it.  
- When everyone gets good at this, you can start moving around the room, still passing the “snap”.  
- Can you throw under the leg? Behind the back? Through your head? Intercept a pass? Have fun with the “snap”!

rows.name: activity_text
rows.value:
Choose a sport or exercise to do together. Decide on a schedule. Are you going to do it every day? For how long? 

Try it out for a week. At the end of the week, ask yourself and your family these questions:
- How is it going? 
- How did you feel at the start of the week? 
- How do you feel at the end of the week? 
- What can we do differently next week?

rows.name: activity_text
rows.value:
Take turns being the “leader”. Say the intro sentences to activate everyone. Then the “leader” gives an instruction and everyone does the activity as fast as possible:
- Leader: “There’s a fire on the mountain!”        
- Together: “Run, run, run!”
- Leader: “There’s a fire on the mountain!”        
- Together: “Run, run, run!”
- Leader: “Touch something red.” 
- Leader: “There’s a fire on the mountain!”        
- Together: “Run, run, run!”
- Leader: “There’s a fire on the mountain!”        
- Together: “Run, run, run!”
- Leader: “Jump up and down ten times.”
- Leader: “There’s a fire on the mountain!”        
- Together: “Run, run, run!”
- Leader: “There’s a fire on the mountain!”        
- Together: “Run, run, run!”
- Leader: “Put the shoes in the shoe rack.”

rows.name: activity_text
rows.value:
This game is best when more than 2 people play.
- One person pretends to be doing something – for example, combing hair or making dinner. 
- Another person asks, “What are you doing?”
- The first person needs to say something that has nothing to do with combing hair, for example, “Tying my shoes.”  
- The second person then starts pretending to tie their shoes until a new person asks, “What are you doing?” 

The answer must always be something different than what you are actually doing!

rows.name: activity_text
rows.value:
- Shake your left hands in the air 8 times while counting to 8.
- Do it as fast and loud as you can.
- Repeat with your other hand. Repeat with both feet.
- Do it 7 times, then 6 times and continue until you get to 1.
- Everyone calls out “Crazy chicken” and does their best crazy chicken dance!

rows.name: activity_text
rows.value:
Sit down, close your eyes and listen to your breath as it goes in and out. 

Notice how you feel. 

When you are ready, open your eyes again.

rows.name: outro_text
rows.value: Try this whenever you are feeling stressed and you need a break to reconnect.

rows.name: activity_text
rows.value:
Close your eyes. 

Let's use the magic power of three to stay present and relax. 

Name three sounds you can hear right now. 
Name three smells you can smell right now. 
Name your three favourite foods. 

What are three things you can be grateful for right now? They don't have to be big.

rows.name: outro_text
rows.value: At the end of a tough day, thinking of three things to be grateful for can help us find the courage to try again tomorrow.

rows.name: activity_text
rows.value:
Close your eyes and think about the day. 

Name 1 thing that you are grateful for. 
Name 1 thing that you did well. 
Name 1 thing that you love.

rows.name: outro_text
rows.value: Well done, you are a hero!

rows.name: activity_text
rows.value:
Close your eyes. 

Use the magic power of three to stay connected and relax.

Breathe in to the count of three. 1, 2, 3. 
Breathe out to the count of three. 1, 2, 3. 
Breathe in to the count of three. 1, 2, 3. 
Breathe out to the count of three. 1, 2, 3.

rows.name: outro_text
rows.value:
Do you feel any different? Deep breathing helps our whole body and mind to calm down. 

You are a star!

rows.name: activity_text
rows.value:
Close your eyes.

Listen to your breath as it goes in and out five times.

Notice how you feel.

rows.name: outro_text
rows.value: When you are ready open your eyes again. You are in control!

rows.name: activity_text
rows.value:
Close your eyes. 

Take a minute to think about the day.

Think about one positive or fun thing you did.
Praise yourself for one thing you did well today. 
Think of one thing you can do differently tomorrow.  
Think of one thing that you are grateful for.

rows.name: activity_text
rows.value:
Close your eyes. 

Do your children ever make you feel like screaming? 

Give yourself a 10-second pause. Breath in and out slowly 5 times. 

Then try responding in a calmer way.

rows.name: outro_text
rows.value: Millions of parents say this helps - A LOT.

rows.name: activity_text
rows.value:
Close your eyes.  

Take a moment to stop what you are doing and connect with your breath.   

What is one thing you can be grateful for right now?  
What is one thing that brings you happiness?  
What is one thing that you love?  

They don't have to be big. Sometimes the small things in life count the most!

rows.name: activity_text
rows.value:
Here's an activity to relax your body:  

Sit comfortably and close your eyes if you can.  
Imagine a golden ring scanning your body from your feet to your head.   
Pay attention as it moves up and down your body. Are there any areas that feel tense? Numb? Painful?   
Focus on those areas for a moment. Breathe in to the area and when you breathe out, try to let go of any tension or pain.   
Do this for a few breaths.   

Open your eyes. How does your body feel now?

rows.name: outro_text
rows.value: You can also try this next time you find yourself lying in bed unable to sleep!

rows.name: activity_text
rows.value:
Close your eyes.  

Notice your connection with the ground beneath you.  
What parts of your body touch the ground? What parts of your body don’t?   
Notice where it feels warm and where it feels cool.  
Feel the ground underneath you supporting you. Let your body sink into the support of the ground.

rows.name: outro_text
rows.value: Try this next time you feel alone or are doing a mundane activity like washing up. It can really help!

rows.name: activity_text
rows.value:
Sit down and close your eyes.
How many sounds can you hear?  
Listen to the sounds inside and outside the room. Count them on your fingers. 
After ten seconds, how many fingers do you have up? What sounds did you hear? 

Try again for another ten seconds.  
Did you hear any new sounds? Did you hear any sounds inside your own body? 
Notice how you feel now.

rows.name: activity_text
rows.value:
Close your eyes.  

Do you every feel something so strongly that you want to run away from it?  

Instead of moving away from the feeling, let’s move towards it for a moment.  
It’s ok. Close your eyes if you feel comfortable. Take a deep breath.  

Become curious. Where are you feeling it in your body? Is it hot or cold? Hard or soft? Tight or loose?  
Ask yourself some questions. What is it telling me? What does it need? How can I be kind to myself right now?

rows.name: activity_text
rows.value:
Here is something fun to help you let go of stress:   

Choose a song that reflects what you need in this moment. Do you need a gentle song to soothe your tired soul or an upbeat song to help you shake some stress out?   

Make a space and move your body to the music. Remember to breathe while you move. Let your breath and the movement go together.

rows.name: outro_text
rows.value: Even a few minutes of movement can be enough to release stress and lift your mood!

rows.name: activity_text
rows.value:
Close your eyes.  
Take a moment to feel the ground under your feet. 
Think of something you feel grateful for.
Focus on your breath.
Breathe in and out.

In and out.

rows.name: activity_text
rows.value:
Hello! How are you feeling right now? Happy, sad, angry, excited, worried?

Notice where you feel it in your body. Notice what thoughts are connected to that feeling. Take a deep breath.

rows.name: outro_text
rows.value: Thank yourself for taking the time to check in with your feelings and thoughts!

rows.name: activity_text
rows.value:
Let’s practice a calming trick that we call ‘Pause Power’. 

Plant your feet on the ground and breathe in and out three times as slowly as you can. Imagine you are smelling a flower or blowing out a candle. 

Ta Da! Pause Power!

rows.name: outro_text
rows.value: This is a great trick to use when you are feeling frustrated because it will help to calm you down.

rows.name: activity_text
rows.value:
Self-praise can be really helpful, especially when we have difficult days. 

Think of your week and finish the following phrase: “This week, I am proud of myself for …” It can be anything, not just things about being a parent!

Think of one thing you did well today. Now wrap your arms around yourself and give yourself a big HUG!

rows.name: activity_text
rows.value:
Sit comfortably and close your eyes. 

Recognise what is happening for you in this moment. What are you thinking? Are your thoughts positive or negative. How do you feel? Do you feel pleasant or unpleasant? How does your body feel? Do you feel tense or relaxed?

Connect to your heart in a kind and gentle way. You may want to place one hand on your heart or chest. Say the following words silently to yourself:

May I be peaceful.
May I be safe.
May I be healthy.
May I be happy.
May there be love in my family.
May I feel loved.

rows.name: outro_text
rows.value: Take a moment to reflect on your experience. Notice if you feel any different.

rows.name: activity_text
rows.value:
Step 1. Close your eyes and take a deep breath. 

Step 2. Ask yourself, "What am I thinking?" Notice if your thoughts are positive or negative.
Notice how you are feeling emotionally. Notice if your emotions are pleasant or unpleasant. Remind yourself that whatever you feel, it is okay.
Notice how your body feels. Notice anything that hurts or is tense.

Step 3. Focus on your breath. Feel your breath as it goes in and out. You can put a hand on your stomach and feel it rise and fall with each breath. Do this for about 10 breaths.

Step 4. Expand your awareness to your whole body. Listen to the sounds in the room. 

Step 5. Take a moment to reflect on whether you feel any different. When you are ready, open your eyes.

rows.name: outro_text
rows.value: Well done for Taking a Pause. You can do this anytime you are feeling stressed. It gives you a chance to be calmer. Even a few deep breaths or connecting with the ground beneath you can make a difference. You can also Take a Pause with your Children!

rows.name: activity_text
rows.value:
Stand up and stretch your arms up to the sky. Push away any clouds and let the sun shine down on you. Stretch to both sides. Stretch to the front and to the back.

Let your hand hang by your side. Squeeze your shoulders tightly up to your ears as you breathe in, scrunch your eyes, and hold your breath. Release your shoulders as you relax your body.

Relax your arms and let your arms to swing sideways, and turn your upper body. Your arms should gently hit your back as you twist from side to side.

Place one foot in front of the other and make small circles from ankles, remember to turn to both sides. Do each foot with four circles in each direction.

Now shake your whole body as fast as you can. Shake it up high! Shake it down low! Shake it all around!

Close your eyes and raise your arms slowly above your head as you breathe in. Lower your arms slowly to your side as you breathe out.

Take a moment to reflect on your experience.

rows.name: outro_text
rows.value: Well done! You can do this activity at any time whenever you feel like you need to release stress and energise your mind and body.

rows.name: activity_text
rows.value:
Make a list of healthy activities that you like to do. Here are some suggestions:
- Listening to your favourite music
- Going for a walk (if allowed)
- Doing some exercise
- Drinking a cup of tea by yourself
- Calling up a friend
- Singing, dancing, praying, or reading
- Sitting in the sun with your eyes closed
- Watching your favourite T.V. show

Pick one and do it today!

rows.name: activity_text
rows.value: When you take care of yourself, you take care of your children. We all need to connect. Try to talk to friends, family, and other support networks every day. If it has been a while since you reached out to someone, do it now!

rows.name: activity_text
rows.value:
Think about what makes you angry? When does it happen? How do you normally react?

Prevent anger from starting in the first place. Get some sleep or rest when you are tired. Try to eat something when you are hungry. Ask someone for support when you are feeling alone.

rows.name: activity_text
rows.value:
Managing anger can be really difficult. Take a break when you feel you are getting angry at your children or someone else.

Go somewhere else for 5 minutes to regain control of your emotions. If you have safe outdoor space, go outside. You can get through this!

rows.name: intro_text
rows.value:
Being a parent can be so hard. Sometimes it feels like our children never listen to us.

But science shows that spending just a few minutes each day of focused one-on-one time with your teen helps build trust and love.

rows.name: text
rows.value:
One-on-one time is when you focus on them, without TV or phones. Let them lead what you do or talk about.

It is great if you can do twenty minutes a day, but even five minutes a day is really good.

rows.name: text
rows.value:
Share ideas! 

What are things you could do to spend one-on-one time with your teens?

Feel like you have NO TIME and you are exhausted? Come up with ideas for one-on-one time that do not take up extra time, like walking to the shop together.

rows.name: outro_text
rows.value:
It may take some time to get used to one-on-one time, but the more you do it the better it gets!

You are amazing parents for trying this.

rows.name: title
rows.value: DAY - Try to do it every day

rows.name: text_1
rows.value: Find 5 minutes (or more!) each day when your teen does not have something else they want to do.

rows.name: text_1
rows.value: Tell your teen that you would like to spend some time with them and that they can choose what to do or talk about. They might think this is weird at first, but will come to enjoy this time with you!

rows.name: text_1
rows.value: Switch off TV and put aside phones. Look at your teen. Nod or say “I see” to show you are really paying attention. Accept what they say without judging them.

rows.name: bottom_text
rows.value: One-on-one time with your teen can be fun for you, too! It might even make you feel less stressed.

rows.name: text_1
rows.value: Spend 5-20 minutes of one-on-one time with your teen, every day you can this week.

rows.name: text_3
rows.value:
Remember - whenever you can, relax, recognise and reward yourself. 

Care for yourself every day. You matter!

rows.name: intro_text
rows.value:
Teenagers often break rules. Growing up is a difficult time when they are learning about who they are. 

Luckily, there are ways to discipline your teen without getting angry or using violence… and they work well!

Giving calm consequences helps teach our children responsibility for what they do – good and bad. 

Here are some examples - imagine you are the parent:

rows.name: outro_text
rows.value:
Calm consequences should be... 

FAIR: Not too harsh and you can actually do it 

IMMEDIATE: Give them as soon as possible 

CONSISTENT: The same consequence every time

rows.name: reply
rows.value:
Consequences are not quite the same as punishment: they give our teens a chance to learn responsibility for their actions.

And they are more controlled AND effective than hitting or shouting!

rows.name: text_1
rows.value:
@global.w_consequence_teen_boy_1 came home late.

What consequence would help here?

value.fullExpression:
@global.w_consequence_teen_boy_1 came home late.

What consequence would help here?

rows.name: text_2
rows.value:
Consequences are not quite the same as punishment: they give our teens a chance to learn responsibility for their actions.

And they are more controlled AND effective than hitting or shouting!

rows.name: reply
rows.value:
Consequences are more successful if you discuss and agree in advance with teens before you apply them.

And: consequences are not all negative… You can also agree on GOOD consequences for GOOD actions to see more positive behaviour!

What consequence would help here?

rows.name: top_text
rows.value: How you introduce calm consequences is important. Remember, when you involve your teen, things usually go better!

rows.name: text_1
rows.value:
Check you are both calm. Take a few breaths. Explain to your teen why you are concerned about their behaviour.

Explain the reasons why the rule mattered. You can share your feelings - it’s okay to say you are disappointed.

rows.name: text_1
rows.value:
Plan consequences with your teen for following and not following the rule.

Ask for their ideas. Talk until you agree on something realistic.

Make a consequence for NOT following the rule and a privilege when they DO follow the rule.

rows.name: subtitle_1
rows.value: When your teen follows the rule, give praise and privileges!

rows.name: text_1
rows.value: They will feel respected and valued. Remember: The more we praise them, the more they will show that good behaviour!

rows.name: subtitle_2
rows.value: When your teen does not follow the rule, follow through with the consequence.

rows.name: text_2
rows.value: When your teen breaks the rule, calmly give the consequence. This should be FAIR (not too harsh), IMMEDIATE (do it straight away) CONSISTENT (same every time).

rows.name: text
rows.value:
Discuss together:
- What rules do your teens often break? 
- What consequence could you use for each specific broken rule? 

Consequences should be: 
FAIR (not too harsh)
IMMEDIATE (do it straight away) 
CONSISTENT (same every time).

Praise and encourage each other – we can give each other strength!

FAIR - IMMEDIATE - CONSISTENT

rows.name: text_1
rows.value:
Your home practice for this week will be to talk together with your teen about a ONE negative consequence and ONE positive consequence.

Consequences should be:
FAIR (not too harsh)
IMMEDIATE (do it straight away)
CONSISTENT (same every time)

rows.name: list_text
rows.value:
Negative Behaviour: Coming home after the agreed hour. 

Negative Consequence: Cannot see friends the next day. 

Negative Behaviour: Talking rudely. 

Negative Consequence: Write a letter of apology. 
 
Positive Behaviour: Helping out with shopping. 

Positive Consequence: 30 minutes extra of loved activity of their choice.  

Positive Behaviour: Helping look after younger siblings. 

Positive Consequence: One hour of extra time with friends on the weekend.

rows.value: All these skills can help in a crisis.

rows.name: top_text
rows.value: Crisis can make us feel angry or helpless. But this is when our teens really need us to breathe, listen and think.

rows.name: text_1
rows.value: Stay calm. Ask yourself ‘what does my teen need right now’

rows.name: text_1
rows.value: Tell them you are there for them and love them.

rows.name: text_1
rows.value: Talk with your teen. What might help the situation? You might need to make immediate plans now, and then long-term plans later.

rows.name: bottom_text
rows.value: You can be proud of yourself for exploring ways to get help!

rows.name: button_1
rows.value: Resources to help in the community

rows.name: intro_text
rows.value:
It’s helpful to practice dealing with crisis before something happens. 

Look at these five family crisis times. Imagine you are the parent: What would you do?

Remember:  BREATHE - LISTEN - THINK

rows.value: Remember to support and encourage each other. It is hard to remain calm and listen to each other in a crisis - we are proud of you.

rows.value:

And remember: BREATHE  - LISTEN - THINK

rows.name: intro_text
rows.value:
Focus on the positive! 

Telling our teens what we DO want them to do works better than telling them to STOP doing something.

You will see the difference.

- Tools: How to give positive instructions
GET REAL - GET POSITIVE - GET CLEAR

rows.name: text
rows.value:
DO NOT THINK ABOUT AN ELEPHANT 

What are you thinking about?

rows.name: text
rows.value:
You probably DID think about an elephant...

‘Don’t do’ instructions make teens think about that thing. 

Sometimes they don’t understand what we DID want from them. 

Also they often don’t like being told not to do things (don’t we all?)

rows.name: text
rows.value:
NOW, THINK ABOUT A CHEETAH! 

What are you thinking about?

rows.name: text
rows.value:
That’s right! Positive, clear instructions help teens focus on what they should be doing. 

Teens will also feel more respected this way, and are more likely to listen.

rows.name: text_1
rows.value: Can your teen actually do what you are about to ask? It may be impossible for them to read quietly all day, but half an hour when you really need it is realistic.

rows.name: text_1
rows.value: Smile, look them in the eye, and use positive words. Praise them as soon as they start to do what you ask!

rows.name: text_1
rows.value: Often we know what we want in our head, but we don’t say it clearly enough. Say exactly what you want your teen to do. Try ‘please come home by 7pm’ instead of ‘come home in time’.

rows.name: intro_text
rows.value: Let's practice giving REAL, POSITIVE and CLEAR instructions. Practice will help you be successful with your teen!

rows.name: text
rows.value:
Choose two people from your group:
- One person pretends to be a teenager
- The other pretends to be the teenager’s parent
- “Parent”: Give your “teen” a positive instruction with encouragement and praise
- “Teen”: Respond as you think a teen may respond to this 

Discuss together how that went:
- How did this make you feel as “parent” and as “teen”?
- Could you do anything better?

Give everyone a chance to be the “parent” and the “teen” if you can. Practice brings success!

rows.name: list_text
rows.value:
- I like your music. Could you turn it down during dinner so that we can talk? Thank you – I really appreciate it. 
- That’s great music. Who is the singer? Please turn the music off when you come in the house. You can play it in your room quietly if you want. Thank you!

rows.name: text_1
rows.value:
This week's home practice is to give your teen positive instructions.

Remember – GET REAL, GET POSITIVE, GET CLEAR = GET EXACTLY WHAT YOU WANT (as much as is possible with a teenager!)

rows.name: text
rows.value: Caring for yourself is so essential.

rows.name: reply_happy
rows.value: Wonderful, I am so happy things are going well. Keep up the good work.

rows.name: reply_ok
rows.value: Sorry that things are difficult now. It is completely normal to struggle sometimes. Remember that you are not alone!

rows.name: reply_sad
rows.value: Sorry that things are difficult now. It is completely normal to struggle sometimes. Remember that you are not alone!

rows.name: bottom_text
rows.value: Take a moment and just be impressed at what you’ve achieved, despite all the other things you have to do each day.

Many families are stressed about money, especially if teens keep asking for things! 

When we make a budget together, we can agree how to spend AND save to prevent stress and work towards our family’s goals.

rows.name: intro_text
rows.value:
It can be hard to make ends meet every month. Many families have this problem! 

Including @global.w_money_grandma - let's have a look:

rows.name: intro_text
rows.value: A family budget can help @global.w_money_grandma - and YOU!

value.fullExpression: A family budget can help @global.w_money_grandma - and YOU!

rows.name: text
rows.value:
There are four steps for doing a family budget: 

Step 1: THINK
Step 2: CHOOSE
Step 3: BUILD
Step 4: PLAN

Let’s go through the steps together. You need:

- Papers (or old newspaper or a cardboard box) and pens
- Stones or beans or anything with lots of bits to represent money
 
Take a minute to get these things before we start with the first step.

rows.name: intro_text
rows.value: Think about what we spend money on each month.

rows.name: text
rows.value:
- Get a piece of paper (or old newspaper or a cardboard box) and a pen. 
- Draw pictures of all the things that you and your family spend money on each month. 
- Write next to each picture how much each thing costs each month. (There is no need to share the numbers if you don’t want to.)
- Add up how much money you have to spend each month.

rows.name: outro_text
rows.value:
Wonderful! You finished step 1! 

Let’s move on!

rows.name: intro_text
rows.value:
Talk together about your needs and wants

WANT: Something you can live without
NEED: Something you cannot live without

rows.name: text
rows.value:
People often don’t see things in the same way. When we talk about our needs and wants, we understand each other better and can make good choices together on how to spend our money.

Look at your lists of things you spend money on and discuss:

- Which are NEEDS that you can’t live without? Why?
- Which are WANTS which are nice to have but not essential? Why? 
- Which things could you try to spend less money on as a family?

- Write down what your income is for the month.
- Take some stones or beans or anything with lots of bits - this is your income for the month. 
(For example: If your income is $100, and you have 20 beans, each bean is $5.  
- Decide what you will spend on what, and put the stones/objects on that image. 

Not sure about your decisions? Having trouble deciding between "needs" and "wants"? That’s totally fine!

rows.name: intro_text
rows.value:
Great work, you have completed the first 3 steps! 

Let's see how @global.w_money_grandma made a plan with her money, just like you are doing:

value.fullExpression:
Great work, you have completed the first 3 steps! 

Let's see how @global.w_money_grandma made a plan with her money, just like you are doing:

rows.name: text
rows.value:
"I want the best future for my grandchildren, but I don’t know where to get the money. Loan sharks are dangerous and paying them back is so expensive. 

I should save, but that feels impossible!"

rows.name: text
rows.value: "My goal is to make sure my grandson can go to high school and my granddaughter can reach her dream of university. How can I save a lot of money with the little money I have?"

rows.name: text
rows.value: "I know - let’s start with a plan! First, let me make a budget – a plan for how I can save my money. Then I will save just a little bit of money at a time – I will even join a savings and loans group."

rows.name: text
rows.value: "I should also speak with my grandchildren to choose things that we can spend just a little bit less on each week. They will help me think of things we want but don’t need."

rows.name: text
rows.value:
A few years later:

"Look, we reached our dreams! I didn’t borrow any money from friends or loan sharks. By saving a tiny bit each week, I managed to pay for @global.w_money_teen_boy’s high school and save some money for @global.w_money_teen_girl’s university. I am so proud of this.”

value.fullExpression:

rows.name: intro_text
rows.value: Saving is important for one more reason: emergencies! @global.w_money_grandma also learned this along the way:

value.fullExpression: Saving is important for one more reason: emergencies! @global.w_money_grandma also learned this along the way:

rows.name: text
rows.value: “One night there was a horrible storm that broke my roof. Everything was flooded. I suddenly had to find money to fix the roof. I just felt defeated.”

rows.name: text
rows.value:
For @global.w_money_grandma, a storm happened. 

What other emergencies could come up for us?

value.fullExpression:
For @global.w_money_grandma, a storm happened. 

What other emergencies could come up for us?

rows.name: outro_text
rows.value: Emergencies can happen in any family. Saving some money for these emergencies BEFORE they happen prevents a lot of sudden worry and stress!

rows.name: intro_text
rows.value: Let's talk about different ways we can save.

rows.name: text
rows.value:
Discuss together: 
- In which different ways can we save?  
- What are the advantages and disadvantages of each savings option? 

Understanding each option well will help you to decide what is the best saving option for your family.  

Whatever savings plan you choose, it will really help your family move forward!

rows.name: intro_text
rows.value: Let's think about different ways we can save.

rows.name: text
rows.value:
There are different ways we can save: at home, buying things we can sell later, at a bank, or in a savings group.

Think of the advantages and disadvantages of each savings option.

rows.name: question_text
rows.value: What is the best savings option for your family?

rows.name: reply
rows.value: Whatever savings plan you choose, it will really help your family move forward!

rows.name: intro_text
rows.value: Plan how you can save money, so you can deal with emergencies and realise your family goals!

rows.name: text
rows.value:
If you can save even a tiny amount for the future or emergency - it can make a big difference over time. 
- Add a circle called “emergencies”.
- Add a circle called “family goals”.
- Now try to move your money around so you can save a bit every month for each of these.

rows.name: outro_text
rows.value: CONGRATULATIONS!!! You’ve made your family budget – and using it will make a huge difference for you. I think every person in your family deserves a praise, don’t you?

rows.value: Talk together about needs and wants

rows.name: text_1
rows.value:
Make a budget again - this time WITH your teen and family! 

This is an important and fun thing to do with your family - it takes about 30 minutes.

Making a budget together helps teens understand that we all need to make hard decisions sometimes - but that it helps us have enough money at the end of the month and realise our goals!

Budgets have helped  millions of families.

rows.name: text_2
rows.value:
Make a budget with your teen and family. 

This is an important and fun thing to do with your family - it takes about 30 minutes.

Making a budget together helps teens understand that we all need to make hard decisions sometimes - but that it helps us have enough money at the end of the month and realise our goals!

Budgets have helped  millions of families.

rows.name: text_3
rows.value:
Review your budget with your teen and family. This will remind everyone that we all need to make hard decisions sometimes - but that it helps us have enough money at the end of the month and realise our goals!

Budgets have helped millions of families.

rows.name: reply_happy
rows.value: Great to hear that you are doing well. You are a wonderful parent!

rows.name: reply_ok
rows.value: Sorry that you are not having the best day. Well done for trying to figure everything out. Nobody has all the answers but you really do your best!

rows.name: reply_sad
rows.value: Sorry to hear that you are not having a good day. Well done for getting up every morning and trying again, even when you are tired. That is real courage and dedication!

Think about how your home activities went this week. 

Take turns to discuss:

- What went well and what was a problem?
- What solutions can you think of together?
- Pick one solution and try it later with your teen! 

(Or you can even practice it now  so it will be easier later!)

rows.name: intro_text
rows.value:
Praise is a powerful parenting skill.

If we praise our teens when they do something well, we will see them do more and more positive things!

- When last did someone thank you or say you did something great? 
- How did it make you feel? 
- How does it feel if you are not thanked or praised for what you do? 

We usually don’t get thanked or praised enough as parents. Maybe you can give your teens the right example and praise them first when they do something well!

rows.name: description_text
rows.value: Sometimes it’s hard to think of what to praise your teen for! Here are some ideas from other parents:

- Coming home in time 
- Showing thoughtfulness 
- Saying 'please' or 'thank you' 
- Going to school  
- Doing chores or schoolwork  
- Getting through mealtime peacefully

rows.name: top_text
rows.value: Household rules help keep our teenagers safe, and understand what is expected from them. When you involve a teenager in making rules they are more likely to follow them.

rows.name: text_1
rows.value: Plan rules WITH your teenager. Start with one new rule first - you can add another one later. Discuss the reasons for the rule and listen to their views.

rows.name: text_1
rows.value: Make them realistic for what your teenager can do, and be clear and specific so there’s no misunderstanding. Not ‘on time’ but ‘by 7pm’.

rows.name: text_1
rows.value: Praise your teen for planning a rule with you, and praise them for keeping it!

rows.name: intro_text
rows.value: Rules are important to keep your teens safe - also online. There’s more about this in the Weekly Workshop on safety planning, but let’s already have a first look now!

rows.name: intro_text
rows.value: Let's talk about our teens' online safety.

rows.name: text
rows.value: What are some of the online risks for teens these days?

rows.name: list_text
rows.value:
- Adults use social media, gaming and messaging apps and websites to meet teenagers and persuade them to do sexual things 
- People put things online to make us hurt other people – like making violence seem cool, or hating people from another race or country
- People put things online to persuade teenagers to hurt themselves or commit suicide
- Teenagers share sexy videos or photos or information about themselves, and people show it to others or use it to upset them
- People can often be nasty to teenagers online – they feel like they can bully people safely

rows.value: Let's think about our teens' online safety.
